WASHINGTON Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton is scheduled to return to the campaign trail on Friday after taking a few days off to recuperate from pneumonia
column2: MSNBC reported on Tuesday.The network
column3: citing what it said was a release from Clinton's campaign
column4: said she was scheduled to appear at a ""Black Women's Agenda"" event in Washington
column5: although it said if she were not feeling well that plan could change.

column1: (Reporting by Timothy Ahmann; Editing by Eric Walsh)"
1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-cyber-congress-idUSKCN11J1QU	McCain vows to block proposed separation of NSA
column2: cyber command	"

column1: By Patricia Zengerle
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON U.S. Senator John McCain said on Tuesday he would use his power to block the confirmation of a key cybersecurity official if necessary to prevent any Obama administration move to separate the U.S. Cyber Command from the National Security Agency.""I do not believe rushing to separate the 'dual hat' in the final months of an administration is appropriate
column2: given the very serious challenges we face in cyberspace
column3: McCain
column4: the Republican chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee
column5: said at a hearing.""Dual hat"" refers to one individual holding both positions.Current and former U.S. officials told Reuters in August that President Barack Obama's administration was preparing to elevate the stature of the Department of Defense's Cyber Command
column6: including separating it from the NSA.

column1: Officials argued that the focus of the NSA
column2: a spy agency responsible for electronic eavesdropping
column3: is gathering intelligence
column4: often favoring the monitoring of an enemy's cyber activities. Cyber Command's mission is geared more to shutting down cyber attacks - and
column5: if ordered
column6: counter attacking.

column1: McCain said the two agencies must work closely together to protect U.S. national security and he would block any nominee if that person was not nominated both to run the NSA and lead Cyber Command.He also said he wanted the administration to provide his panel with detailed plans of its proposed reorganization.
This committee does not take well to being stonewalled while their colleagues in the administration leak information to the press
column2: McCain said.Admiral Mike Rogers
column3: the current NSA director and head of Cyber Command
column4: told the hearing that he did not think it was in the best U.S. national security interest at this point to separate the two functions. (Reporting by Patricia Zengerle; Editing by Bill Trott)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-idUSKCN11J1IV	In Pennsylvania
column2: Trump to propose childcare deduction tax break	"

column1: By Steve Holland
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump on Tuesday will propose allowing families to deduct the cost of childcare expenses from income taxes
column2: his campaign said
column3: a move aimed at bolstering his support among women voters.Trump is to lay out the plan in an evening speech in the Philadelphia suburb of Aston
column4: Pennsylvania
column5: his latest attempt to construct a policy framework that he would use for governing if elected over Democrat Hillary Clinton on Nov. 8.Trump is to be introduced at the event by his daughter
column6: Ivanka
column7: who has championed the issue of childcare as an influential voice in his campaign. She told reporters on a conference call that she was involved in developing the plan.""I'm very passionate about this
column8: she said.Trump's support among women voters has lagged. Overall
column9: he has risen to a more competitive position against Clinton in national opinion polls and in battleground states where the election is likely to be decided.

column1: Polls show the race tightening in the crucial state of Pennsylvania. A Quinnipiac University poll last week said Clinton led 48 percent to 43 percent for Trump there
column2: a reduction from her 10-point lead a month ago.Trump's plan would change the U.S. tax code to let parents deduct from their income taxes childcare expenses for up to four children and elderly dependents
column3: his campaign said.It would be available for individuals earning less than $250
column4: 000 a year or under $500
column5: 000 for couples filing jointly.

column1: Trump campaign officials did not detail the overall cost of the program. A senior official said it would be part of Trump's plan to overhaul the tax code and would end up not adding to deficit spending in the U.S. budget.Trump would offer childcare spending rebates to lower-income taxpayers through the existing Earned Income Tax Credit. The campaign said this could mean tax rebates as high as $1
column2: 200 for eligible families each year.

column1: Trump also would create new Dependent Care Savings Accounts to allow families to set aside money ""to foster their children's development and offset elder care for their parents or adult dependents
column2: the campaign said. Individuals could contribute up to $2
column3: 000 a year tax free.The New York businessman also is proposing guaranteed six weeks of paid maternity leave. He would accomplish this by amending the existing unemployment insurance that companies are required to carry. The benefit would apply only when employers do not offer paid maternity leave
column4: and would be paid for by offsetting reductions in the federal unemployment insurance program so that taxes are not raised. (Reporting By Steve Holland; Editing by Bill Trott)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-health-idUSKCN11I2OF	How to get sick on the U.S. campaign trail: Little sleep
column2: bad food
column3: germs everywhere	"

column1: By Steve Holland and Emily Stephenson
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Hillary Clinton's bout of pneumonia has shed light on a problem seldom seen by American voters: The long days
column2: little sleep
column3: cross-country travel
column4: bad food and kissing babies add up to a recipe for illness for presidential candidates and aides.Avoiding viruses and other ailments can be next to impossible for people who spend months in the close confines of campaign planes and buses.Brooke Buchanan
column5: former press secretary to 2008 Republican presidential candidate Senator John McCain
column6: remembers leaving the campaign trail in Beaufort
column7: South Carolina to visit an emergency room. She had a respiratory ailment and two ear infections.""You have to soldier on during certain things
column8: but there's a point when you become a liability
column9: Buchanan said. ""I was back on the road the next day
column11: who will face Republican Donald Trump in the Nov. 8 election
column12: worried on Monday that the Democratic presidential nominee's medical scare would fuel conspiracy theories about her health. But Republican and Democratic political veterans alike say illnesses are an unwelcome but standard part of life on the campaign trail.Alice Stewart
column13: who was a senior adviser to former presidential candidate Senator Ted Cruz during the Republican primary earlier this year
column14: remembers coughing her way through some of his news conferences while she was recording them for the campaign. She called the Cruz plane a ""flying petri dish.""""You just kind of power through it. When you're on the road
column17: several staff at Clinton's campaign's Brooklyn headquarters have fallen ill and required medical treatment
column19: a pulmonary specialist at the University of Kansas
column20: said candidates were particularly vulnerable to illness.""The average patient
column21: if you have the luxury of it
column22: takes the week off before you go back to your full duties
column23: Simpson said. ""But how do you say that to a presidential candidate?""

column1: OBAMA'S HANDKERCHIEF
President Barack Obama caught a cold in August 2008
column2: shortly before the Democratic Party's convention. A video posted on YouTube shows him sneezing at a rally. ""That's why I've got my handkerchief
column3: he said.""Every candidate and campaign aide gets sick
column4: but they just never get to take days off
column5: said former Obama aide Dan Pfeiffer. ""You take vitamin C and try to get sleep
column6: but it's a losing battle.""Obama's 2008 opponent
column8: traveled at times with a friend who was a doctor
column10: the Republican candidate's campaign manager.""I think one of the secrets of working in a White House or on a presidential campaign is it's the closest you can ever get to traveling with Elvis (Presley) when it comes to the number of pills that are floating around

column1: There was always a big bag of every conceivable type of antibiotic and cold medicine
column2: and you name it - we had it.""Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney developed a respiratory illness days before delivering his acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention in Tampa in 2012.""I was scared to death that he wouldn't really be able to speak
column3: said Stuart Stevens
column4: who was Romney's senior adviser. ""Doctors tell you to rest. But there's no time for that.""The grueling schedule led Stevens himself to develop pneumonia right after the 2012 campaign ended.

column1: CANDY BARS AND SAUSAGES
Unhealthy food is another hazard of the campaign trail. Junk food is ubiquitous on campaign planes
column2: and candidates flock to gatherings such as the Iowa State Fair that serve up fried candy bars
column3: sausages and other high-calorie fare.Romney
column4: who also ran for president in 2008
column5: would sometimes pick the cheese off his pizza and the skin off fried chicken to limit the fat content
column6: said former spokesman Ryan Williams.""It's not healthy food
column8: said Williams. ""And most operatives see themselves put on 10 or 20 pounds by the end of the campaign.""Trump is a noted germophobe
column9: and there has been little evidence of him having gotten ill. He is a proud consumer of fast food
column10: once tweeting a photo of himself on his plane with a bucket of Kentucky Fried Chicken nearby.That was also the chicken of choice for 1996 Republican nominee Bob Dole
column11: who managed to avoid getting sick throughout his campaign
column13: Nelson Warfield.""Much of the campaign staff that was half his age were hobbled at some point or another during the campaign
column16: Dole had one nasty stumble. He fell off a stage in Chico
column19: 1996. He got up smiling and soldiered on. (Reporting by Steve Holland and Emily Stephenson
column20: additional reporting by Alana Wise in Washington and Amanda Becker in New York
column21: editing by Caren Bohan and Ross Colvin)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-cyber-governance-idUSKCN11I2OT	U.S. tech firms urge Congress to allow internet domain changeover	"
By Dustin Volz
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Major technology companies including Facebook
column2: Google and Twitter are urging Congress to support a plan for the U.S. government to cede control of the internet's technical management to the global community
column3: they said in a joint letter dated on Tuesday.The U.S. Commerce Department has primary oversight of the internet's management
column4: largely because it was invented in the United States. Some Republican lawmakers are trying to block the handover to global stakeholders
column5: which include businesses
column6: tech experts and public interest advocates
column7: saying it could stifle online freedom by giving voting rights to authoritarian governments.The years-long plan to transfer oversight of the nonprofit Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers
column9: is scheduled to occur on Oct. 1 unless Congress votes to block the handover. The California-based corporation operates the database for domain names such as .com and .net and their corresponding numeric addresses that allow computers to connect. In the Sept. 13 letter
column10: a copy of which had been reviewed by Reuters before it was sent
column11: the technology companies said it was ""imperative"" that Congress does not delay the transition.

column1: A global
column2: interoperable and stable Internet is essential for our economic and national security
column3: and we remain committed to completing the nearly twenty year transition to the multi stakeholder model that will best serve U.S. interests
column4: the letter said. Other signatories include Amazon
column5: Cloudflare
column6: Yahoo and several technology trade organizations.

column1: Former presidential hopeful Senator Ted Cruz of Texas
column2: who leads the opposition against the handover
column3: will hold a congressional hearing on Wednesday to review the transition
column4: which he has criticized as a ""giveaway of our internet freedom.""Tech companies
column5: technical experts and academics have said the transition is overdue and necessary to keep the Internet open and globally oriented
column6: and that the proposal includes safeguards against any potential abuse by any one country.

column1: (This version of the story adds dropped word in fourth paragraph) (Reporting by Dustin Volz; Editing by Richard Chang)"
5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-hotel-idUSKCN11I25L	Trump luxury hotel opens just blocks from the White House	"
By Ian Simpson
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump opened the latest outpost in his real estate empire on Monday
column2: a luxury hotel in a historic building five blocks from the White House that underwent a two-year
column3: $200 million renovation.While staff members at the 263-room Trump International Hotel planned little hoopla for what they described as a ""soft opening
column4: about 40 protesters opposed to the New York real estate developer's presidential run gathered outside. The opening came eight weeks before the Nov. 8 election.""It kind of fits his personality that he finds a way to be on Pennsylvania Avenue
column5: one way or another
column6: said protester Judy Byron
column11: is less than a mile (km) down Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House. The hotel is housed in Washington's third-tallest building
column13: built in the Romanesque Revival architectural style.Trump said on Twitter he had stopped by the property ""to thank all of the tremendous men & women for their hard work!""The protesters criticized some of Trump's positions
column14: including a promise to build a wall along the Mexican border to block illegal immigrants. Protest organizer Andrew Castro of Baltimore said: ""We're out here building a wall against racism.""

column1: Dozens of people filtered in and out on Monday afternoon
column2: some to gawk and others pausing for a drink at the hotel's bar.On his way in
column3: Ric Hedlund
column4: who works in port development
column5: said he had been impressed by the renovations of a building that he said was previously ""a dump.""""I'm going in to drink Trump wine
column6: said Hedlund
column7: who added he also supported Trump as a candidate.

column1: Trump's daughter Ivanka
column2: who helped negotiate the 60-year lease with the U.S. government and oversaw the building's revamp and design
column3: said the project had come in a year ahead of schedule and under budget.""We have really positioned this hotel to not only be the finest hotel in D.C. but in the country
column4: she said in a telephone interview.A grand-opening ceremony is planned for next month.

column1: Trump attended the 2014 groundbreaking for the renovations alongside local Democratic officials before launching his presidential campaign last year.While Trump's name is hard to escape in his native New York
column2: where it adorns structures including the Trump Tower as well as a Bronx golf course
column3: the hotel marks his most visible presence in Washington.His comments describing some Mexican immigrants as criminals prompted celebrity chefs Jose Andres and Geoffrey Zakarian to pull out of the project. Trump has sued them. (Additional reporting by Kouichi Shirayanagi in Washington; Amy Tennery in New York; Editing by Andrew Hay and Peter Cooney)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-rates-idUSKCN11I19H	Trump says Fed keeping rates low because of pressure from Obama	"

WASHINGTON Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump said on Monday that U.S. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen was keeping interest rates low because of political pressure from the Obama administration
column2: questioning the motives of an institution whose work hinges on maintaining its independence.""Well
column3: it's (the interest rate) staying at zero because she's obviously political and she's doing what Obama wants her to do
column4: Trump told CNBC in a phone interview
column5: saying Yellen should be ""ashamed"" of what she was doing to the country.The U.S. central bank has raised interest rates just once since cutting them to zero in response to the 2008 financial crisis. The Fed has indicated it is preparing for a second hike of 0.25 percentage point
column6: although it has signaled the pace of future rate rises will be slower than in the past.""Any increase at all will be a very
column7: very small increase because they want to keep the market up so Obama goes out and let the new guy ... raise interest rates ... and watch what happens in the stock market
column8: Trump said.He did not specify how the Democratic president had put pressure on Yellen.While Yellen has met with Obama
column9: the Fed as an institution is independent when it comes to raising or lowering rates
column10: and both Yellen and other rate-setters have said the Fed has no view on the Nov. 8 election.The Fed's Washington-based board had no comment on Trump's remarks
column11: though regional Federal Reserve bank presidents said during public appearances that politics do not enter into Fed deliberations.Minneapolis Federal Reserve President Neel Kashkari responded in a later interview on CNBC by denying that politics influenced Fed policymaking.

column1: Politics simply does not come up
column2: he said. ""We look at the economic data and ... everyone around the table is committed to achieving our dual mandate"" of maximum employment and stable prices
column3: Kashkari said.  Atlanta Fed President Dennis Lockhart
column4: asked about political pressure on the Fed at a National Association for Business Economics conference in Atlanta
column5: said
column6: ""I don't see the world that way.""Trump's comments mark a back-and-forth by the candidate over whether he feels low rates are good or bad. He has accused the Fed of keeping rates low at Obama's behest
column7: but at other times has said he felt lower rates were good because higher rates would make the dollar stronger
column8: hurting American exports and manufacturers. As a businessman
column11: but said they hurt many people who were living on their savings.

column1: STEERING CLEAR OF POLITICS
Typically
column2: Fed officials steer clear of politics in their public remarks
column3: and argue that doing so is important for the Fed to maintain the independence it needs to set monetary policy.The moments when the line is publicly breached
column4: such as former Chair Alan Greenspan's endorsement of a Bush administration tax cut
column5: are rare and can provoke a quick backlash.

column1: Though the members of the Fed's Board of Governor's are appointed by the president with Senate confirmation
column2: their long
column3: 14-year terms and staggered appointment dates are designed to insulate them from the sort of pressure Trump alleges. The chair
column4: considered one of the most powerful positions in setting U.S. economic policy
column5: is picked from the board members for a four-year term. Yellen's would expire in 2018
column6: and Trump has previously said he would consider replacing her.The Fed's marching orders
column9: which has set the central bank's mandate.The Fed lowered interest rates to near zero in response to the 2007-2009 financial crisis
column10: and has increased them only once since then - in December - given the sluggish pace of the recovery.Fed members and economists have vigorously debated the issue Trump raised - whether easy-money policies have led to an unsustainable rise in asset prices. But there has been even more concern about weak growth
column12: and the need to keep financial conditions loose to try to ensure businesses keep hiring. (Reporting by Eric Walsh; Editing by Nick Zieminski and Jonathan Oatis)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN11I0MT	'I didn't think it was a big deal
column2: ' Clinton says of pneumonia bout	"

column1: By Alana Wise and Jeff Mason
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Democrat Hillary Clinton said on Monday she could resume presidential campaigning in a couple of days after a bout of pneumonia that she initially had not believed was ""that big a deal.""Clinton's health scare after she almost collapsed at an event on Sunday
column2: causing her to cancel some campaign trips
column3: revived concerns about a tendency toward secrecy that has dogged her campaign
column4: and underscored perennial worries about the medical fitness of candidates for one of the world's most demanding jobs.""Well
column5: it will be in the next couple of days. ... I just want to get this over and done with and get back on the trail as soon as possible
column6: she said in an interview on CNN on Monday night
column7: adding she had ignored doctor's orders to rest. ""I just didn't think it was going to be that big a deal."" Her campaign acknowledged on Monday it may have been too slow disclosing her pneumonia diagnosis after she nearly fainted at a New York memorial ceremony for the Sept. 11
column9: attacks. She was diagnosed with the lung infection on Friday.""I think that in retrospect
column10: we could have handled it better in terms of providing more information more quickly
column11: Clinton spokesman Brian Fallon told MSNBC earlier in the day.The health problem was the latest blow for the Democratic presidential nominee at a time when Republican rival Donald Trump has erased most of her lead in national opinion polls and is competitive again in many battleground states where the Nov. 8 election is likely to be decided.Clinton
column13: said she had dealt with similar episodes of dizziness before. ""You know
column14: it is something that has occurred a few times over the course of my life. I'm aware of it and usually can avoid it
column15: she told CNN.Asked if she passed out during the incident on Sunday
column17: I didn't. I felt dizzy and I did lose my balance for a minute. Once I got in. Once I could sit down. Once I could cool off. Once I had some water
column18: I immediately started feeling better.""  Her campaign said her husband
column20: would campaign on her behalf while she rests.

column1: Both Clinton and Trump
column3: said they intended to release more of their medical details in the coming days
column4: as their campaigns gear up for the November election.'DEEPLY SHOCKED'

column1: Questions about the incident reinforced the perception of Clinton as secretive
column2: a view fueled by the controversy surrounding her use of a private email server while serving as President Barack Obama's secretary of state from 2009 to 2013.A federal investigation of that issue said she was ""extremely careless"" in her handling of classified emails
column3: but did not recommend criminal charges.Trump said on Monday that health was a campaign issue but he did not attack Clinton over her physical condition. ""I just hope she gets well and gets back on the trail
column4: he said in an interview with Fox News.

column1: He focused his criticism on comments by Clinton last week in which she dismissed half of his supporters as a ""basket of deplorables"" of racist
column2: homophobic people. Clinton said she regretted the remark.Trump has compared the comment with a much-criticized remark by 2012 Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney that 47 percent of the electorate was dependent on the government.""I was deeply shocked and alarmed to hear my opponent attack
column3: slander
column4: smear
column5: demean these wonderful
column6: amazing people who are supporting our campaign by the millions
column7: Trump told a conference of National Guard members in Baltimore.Trump has himself aroused controversy with comments in which he called some Mexican immigrants criminals and rapists
column8: questioned whether a U.S.-born judge could be fair because of his Mexican heritage and criticized the Muslim parents of an American soldier who died in combat in Iraq.

column1: 'SHORT-TERM TURBULENCE'
Clinton's pneumonia disclosure was made public hours after her campaign said she had become ""overheated"" to explain why
column2: her knees buckling and unsteady
column3: she was rushed from the Sept. 11 ceremony.""The short-term turbulence will be more about the handling of this than the substance
column4: David Axelrod
column5: a former political adviser to Obama
column6: told Reuters. ""Antibiotics can take care of pneumonia
column7: Axelrod tweeted later. ""What's the cure for an unhealthy penchant for privacy that repeatedly creates unnecessary problems?""Trump had suggested for weeks that Clinton lacked the energy needed to be president. He has raised questions about her stamina
column8: reprising a tactic from the Republican primary campaign when he derided rival Jeb Bush as a ""low-energy"" candidate. Democrats said her attendance at events despite her pneumonia diagnosis proved her toughness.Trump's campaign has issued a short letter from his doctor saying he was in excellent health with ""extraordinary"" strength and stamina. But the letter did not mention what medicine Trump might be taking or other details typically included in such disclosures.In July 2015
column9: Clinton released a two-page letter outlining her medical condition that sought to reassure Americans about her health after she fell and suffered a concussion at home in 2012 near the end of her tenure as secretary of state. (Additional reporting by Steve Holland
column12: Eric Beech and James Oliphant; Writing by Richard Valdmanis; Editing by Jonathan Oatis and Peter Cooney)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-california-corruption-calderon-idUSKCN11J02N	Former California lawmaker sentenced for laundering bribe to his brother	"
SACRAMENTO
column2: Calif. A former California lawmaker was sentenced to six months in prison and six months in home confinement Monday for laundering a bribe accepted by his brother
column3: also a former legislator.Thomas Calderon
column5: pleaded guilty on June 6 to one count of money laundering in the case. He admitted to depositing $30
column6: 000 in an account held by his political consulting company
column8: that had been offered as a bribe by an undercover agent to his brother in 2013
column9: the U.S. Department of Justice said Monday.""Tom Calderon was all too aware of the bribe payments to his brother and that his brother had agreed to a quid pro quo with the undercover agents
column10: United States Attorney Eileen M. Decker said in a press release. ""Tom Calderon facilitated these bribe payments by helping to conceal his brother's corrupt activities from the public.""Calderon's attorney
column12: said the longtime political hand from the blue collar Los Angeles suburb of Montebello was deeply remorseful for his actions.

column1: If he had it to do all over again he would obviously make a different decision
column2: Kopp said. ""But it's important to view Tom and his life and public service as a whole rather than this one episode. He's been trying to better the lives of the people in his community on the east side of Los Angeles for more than 30 years.""He was sentenced Monday by U.S. District Court Judge Christina Snyder to a year and a day in custody - half of it in federal prison - and 100 hours of community service.

column1: Calderon
column2: a Democrat
column3: served in the state assembly from 1998 to 2002
column4: representing Montebello and other suburbs northeast of Los Angeles.

column1: His brother
column2: Ronald Calderon
column4: also of Montebello
column5: was a Democratic state senator in 2013
column6: when the FBI raided his office as part of the corruption case. The brothers were indicted in the case the following year. Ron Calderon
column7: who took a leave of absence from the state Senate until his term ended in 2014
column8: pleaded guilty to mail fraud in the case and is set to be sentenced next week. (Reporting by Sharon Bernstein; Editing by Bernard Orr)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-obamacare-insurers-idUSKCN11I2ML	Obama asks U.S. insurers for help enrolling the young and healthy	"
President Barack Obama on Monday urged U.S. insurers offering coverage next year under his national healthcare law to step up their efforts to enroll those who remain uninsured
column2: especially younger and healthier Americans.Several big insurers
column3: including UnitedHealth Group Inc
column4: Aetna Inc and Humana Inc
column5: have announced they will pull back from the Obamacare individual insurance market in 2017
column6: citing financial losses due to the costs of covering members who are sicker than expected.Their planned exit has prompted new questions over whether Obamacare can survive over the long-term if insurers cannot create a viable business from the market. Insurance premiums for consumers have jumped each year since Obamacare plans took effect in 2014
column7: and those price increases are expected to grow steeper as fewer insurers participate. Obama
column8: in a letter to all insurers selling health plans next year on the exchanges
column9: noted that the program has helped reduce the percentage of Americans without health insurance to a record low
column10: and acknowledged that it could still be improved to benefit insurers and consumers.

column1: His administration will help find and enroll those who still lack coverage
column2: with a particular focus on enrolling young adults. ""Since the remaining uninsured are disproportionately younger and healthier
column3: signing them up improves the risk pool and consequently the affordability of coverage for all enrollees
column4: Obama said in the letter.

column1: Obama
column2: Secretary of Health and Human Services Sylvia Burwell and other top health advisers on Monday met with executives from several leading insurance companies
column3: including Cigna Corp Chief Executive David Cordani and Humana CEO Bruce Broussard
column4: to discuss ways to strengthen the marketplace ahead of its fourth open enrollment period
column5: which begins Nov. 1
column6: according to a White House official.        A spokeswoman for industry group America's Health Insurance Plans said the meeting's focus included increasing enrollment.

column1: As health plans are preparing for open enrollment
column2: today's meeting was focused on how to build on the continued progress in reducing the uninsured rate and moving forward with policy solutions that will support a stable
column3: affordable market for 2017 and beyond
column4: AHIP spokeswoman Clare Krusing said. (Reporting by Susan Kelly in Chicago)"
